newsitem.title: USA: Michigan Democrats outline legislative proposals.
newsitem.headline: Michigan Democrats outline legislative proposals.

text.p: Just hours before Michigan Gov. John Engler was to give his state of the state address Tuesday evening, Democrats in the state House released their legislative agenda.

The Democrats, who took over control of the House from Republicans following the Nov. 5 election, called for tax credits for low-income residents and for the care of children, the elderly and the disabled.
The lawmakers also proposed an income tax credit for families with children in college and the removal of a five-year limit for senior citizens to defer paying their property taxes.
Other items on the agenda included the reinstatement of uniform academic standards for schools in basic subjects and the repeal of a new law that requires photo identification to vote in elections.

House Speaker Curtis Hertel, D-Detroit, said that voters "sent a clear signal by dividing" the state government in the last election. And he called on Republicans in the legislature and the Republican governor to "work with us in a bipartisan spirit to help improve the lives of Michigan's working families."
Engler is expected to outline his agenda for the year during his state of the state speech Tuesday evening.
